page.title: 10THE WILDLIFE OF PADBURY
page.content: This area only 50 miles from London is fortunate in its abundance of wildlife Foxes abound here as they do in many areas. The disused railway line is a popular haunt for rabbits, perhaps the soil here is easier to burrow through than the local clay. Hares can be seen in the cornfields. Weasels, grey squirrels, badgers and muntjac deer can be seen from time to time. The tributary of the Great Ouse which winds through the fields is the haunt of water voles, several species of duck, herons and even kingfishers. Swans breed in the area and Canada geese overwinter in the meadows . The disused railway is a haven to many species of insect, particularly butterflies. The Orange Tip,Brimstone Comma,Large White,Common Blue,Peacock, Red Admiral,Toroiseshell and Small Copper can all be seen here.
